intro: Cyrtandra paludosa var. degenerans, commonly known as the swamp cyrtandra, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of the Pacific. It belongs to the Gesneriaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically white or pale pink, often clustered in inflorescences. It thrives in wet, shaded environments such as swamps and streambanks, where it forms dense, low-growing mats. Due to its unique morphology and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
